bad.work: The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death: 'But Hope Rekindled, Only to Illume the Shades of Death, and Light her to the Tomb'

title.reg: The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death: 'But Hope Rekindled, Only to Illume the Shades of Death, and Light her to the Tomb'

titlestmt.title: The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death: "But Hope Rekindled, Only to Illume the Shades of Death, and Light her to the Tomb" : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 97KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 137KB to 1200KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesMay 2014
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of the following works related to Blake’s development of his illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave: Preliminary Sketches for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Pencil Sketches; Preliminary Drawings for Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Monochrome Wash Drawings; and Preliminary Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
In addition, we are republishing the following works, previously presented in our Preview mode, to make their designs fully searchable: Robert Blair, The Grave, the 1808 book listed under Commercial Book Illustrations, Designed by Blake and Engraved by Other Engravers; Deaths Door, listed under Separate Plates and Plates in Series, Designed and Engraved by Blake; and Illustrations to Robert Blair’s The Grave, the series of twenty finished designs, listed under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings.
Taken together, these works in a variety of media present a comprehensive overview of one of Blake’s major projects as an illustrator and exemplify his working methods as he developed rough sketches into finished water colors. The evolution of any one design can be traced via links presented under Related Works in the Archive on the pull-down menus, lower left on the main viewing page for each work.
In October 1805, Blake was commissioned by the engraver and would-be publisher Robert H. Cromek to prepare forty drawings illustrating Robert Blair's The Grave, a popular "Graveyard" school poem first published in 1743. Cromek originally planned to select twenty of these designs for a deluxe edition of the poem. Blake launched into the project with great enthusiasm, rapidly sketching out his illustrations in pencil, developing some into wash drawings, and then producing a group of more finished water colors for presentation to Cromek. In a first prospectus of November 1805, Cromek names Blake as both the designer and engraver of fifteen designs. Blake etched one image, Deaths Door, in white-line, but Cromek rejected it. The dark power of the print appeals to modern tastes, but was far from fashionable in the early nineteenth century. In a second prospectus, also of November 1805, Cromek announced that Louis Schiavonetti would engrave twelve designs for the new edition. Blake had lost the potentially lucrative commission to engrave his own designs; his relationship with Cromek descended into anger and argument. In spite of their disagreement, Cromek included a portrait of Blake as a frontispiece to the volume, published in 1808. Cromek promoted the book aggressively and the illustrations to The Grave became Blake's best known work through much of the nineteenth century.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

title.hi: The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death: 'But Hope Rekindled, Only to Illume the Shades of Death, and Light Her to the Tomb'

objinfo.leafsize: 24.2 x 26.6 cm.The leaf appears to have been trimmed slightly, particularly on the right margin.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably commissioned and acquired by Thomas Butts c. 1805; probably by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold anonymously (possibly Thomas Butts, Jr.) at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 174, titled "But hope rekindled only to illume" (£1.1s. to "Evans," probably either the dealer Edward Evans or the dealer R. H. Evans); Anne (Mrs. Alexander) Gilchrist by 1863; by inheritance in 1885 to her son, Herbert Harlakenden Gilchrist; sold by H. H. Gilchrist to the British Museum in 1894.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Prints and Drawings: prints@britishmuseum.org
URL, Department of Prints and Drawings: http://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/departments/prints_and_drawings.aspx

objtitle.title: The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death: 'But Hope Rekindled, Only to Illume the Shades of Death, and Light Her to the Tomb'

objnote.p: Although identical in subject, and compositionally related, to Blake's illustration of *The Descent of Man into the Vale of Death* for Robert Blair's *The Grave*, commissioned by Robert H. Cromek in 1805, this work would appear to be independent of that commission. It may have been commissioned by Thomas Butts. Blake signed the work lower left with his monogram; see the textual transcription.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the design shows an elaborate cave, bisected by a set of stone stairs and marked by four alcoves. At the top of the stairs stands a winged, gowned female angel. She may personify Hope. She carries an (oil?) lamp, from which beams of light emanate. She faces forward but turns to look left. Her long hair is pulled up into a bun and her left arm is at her side, palm down. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and she holds the lamp in her right hand. Both her feet are on tiptoe, and her right leg is bent and extended backward slightly as she descends the stairs. Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The topmost figure is a gowned female with long hair, facing right. Her right leg is bent and extended backward on tiptoe and she hunches slightly forward. Her arms are at her side but bent to hold a child, likely her own. The second figure from the top is a child, perhaps an infant, that sits in its mother's arms. He(?) appears to be nude with short hair. His legs are bent and drawn up. The third figure from the top is a male dressed in a loincloth, facing forward and looking left. He has short, curly hair. His arms are at his sides but bent slightly, palms down. Both of his legs are bent, with the left leg extended backward and on tiptoe. The fourth figure from the top is an old, gowned male with long hair and a beard. He appears to enter an alcove, which may lead farther downward into another section of the cave. He faces left and away, with his left arm at his side, palm downward. His left leg is extended backward and on tiptoe, with his left foot visible beneath the hem of his gown. The fifth and sixth figures from the top are two gowned children. The leftmost of the pair is a boy with short, curly hair, who faces forward and left but looks up and to the right, perhaps at the child to the right. His legs are slightly bent and his right foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown. His arms are at his side but bent to hold the hand of the figure to either side. The rightmost child of this pair is a girl with long hair. Her head is down with her left hand on her face. She may be crying. Her arms are at her side, with her left arm bent upward and her right hand holding the hand of the boy to the left. Her left leg is bent slightly and on tiptoe. The seventh figure from the top is a gowned woman with long, curly hair. She is likely the mother of the three children who stand around her. She faces forward and left, but looks up and to the right. Her mouth may be slightly open. Her right leg is extended backward slightly and on tiptoe. Her arms are at her side and she holds the hands of the children to either side. The eighth figure from the top is a gowned child of indeterminable gender, with long, curly hair. The child faces left and forward but looks up and to the right, probably at its mother. Its left foot is visible beneath the hem of its gown and its arms are at its side, its left hand holding that of the woman to the right. The ninth and tenth figures from the top are a pair of gowned, old figures with long hair. The leftmost figure is a male with a long beard. He faces right and down slightly, looking at the figures to the right. His left leg is bent backward slightly on tiptoe. His right arm is at his side but bent and he holds onto a walking stick or cane with his right hand. The rightmost figure is a woman who faces right and hunches over slightly, looking down and to the right. Her left leg is bent and her arms are at her sides but bent upward, palms vertical, in a gesture of surprise. In the top right alcove in the central cave, four figures are visible. Two figures, which may represent dead bodies or stone tomb effigies, lie supine on a slab of stone or marble, which is marked with carvings of Gothic arches. The topmost figure faces forward slightly. The bottommost figure faces up and may have long hair, its left arm at its side. Both figures are gowned. To the right of the tomb are two gowned figures, facing right and only visible as upper bodies. The leftmost figure of the pair is an old man with a bald crown but long hair and a beard. His arms are at his side but bent upward so that his hands are clasped, as though in prayer. The rightmost figure is a woman with long hair. Her mouth may be slightly open and she bends forward. Her arms are at her side but bent upward with her hands together as though praying. Two gowned figures lie in the bottom right alcove of the central cave on a partly rolled woven mat. The topmost figure of the pair is a male with short, curly hair. His lower body faces up but he twists at the waist so that his upper body faces forward. He looks down and to the right at the face of the figure below him. His right arm is at his side but bent upward, palm raised. His left arm curves around the head of the woman next to him, cradling it. The bottommost figure of the pair is a female whose long hair may be pulled back into a bun. She faces up, with her head bent back. Her mouth is open and her eyes are closed, suggesting that she may be sleeping, fainting, or dying. Her left arm is at her side and is resting on the ground, palm up. In the bottom left alcove of the central cave are four gowned figures. Toward the back of the alcove, an old male figure with long hair and a beard lies supine, eyes closed. He faces up and right. He may be dead or sleeping. He lies on a pillow cushion atop a stone slab carved with arches on the side. Two figures kneel in front of the tomb. The leftmost figure is of indeterminable gender, with long hair covering its face. It faces left and bends forward, head down. The figure sits on a step, legs bent. Its left arm is bent upward, resting on its left leg, with its left hand on its face. The rightmost figure of the pair is a female with long, curly hair. She faces away and to the left, bending forward slightly. She may look at the figure to the right. The rightmost of the four figures is a male with short, curly hair. He faces away, with his lower body facing left and his upper body twisted to face right. He looks to the right as well. His arms are at his side but bent upward, palms up. His left leg is bent backward and on tiptoe as he steps down from a stair into the alcove. The curved top of the central cave frames a scene at the top of the image, including four hills or mountaintops and a clear sky. At the top left corner of the design stands a house with a thatched roof and the frontmost wall missing. Along the back wall stands an open, arched doorway. Two figures are visible inside the house. The leftmost figure is a gowned male with short, curly hair, lying supine on a pillow and woven mat. His right arm is resting at his side and his eyes are closed, suggesting that he is dead. Above him is a gowned female with long curly hair. She kneels(?), facing left and slightly forward. She bends down, looking at the figure to the left. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms vertical and her mouth is open in a gesture of surprise and perhaps mourning. To the right of the house hovers or flies a nude male figure with curly hair, seen from behind. This may represent the soul of the man in the house to the left. His body faces right but his head turns to look left. His legs are together but bent and extended backward. His arms are raised at 45 degrees, palms down. The hill or mountaintop second from the left has a cave visible in the front and ten figures climbing it. Two gowned figures facing right and ascending the mountain stand on the left side of the mountaintop. The leftmost of the two figures may be bald and has its right arm at its side. The rightmost of these two figures may be a male with short hair. His right leg is extended backward and his right arm is raised horizontally, holding a walking stick with his right hand. The five(?) figures walking or standing on the top of the mountain face right; all appear to be gowned. The figures second, third, and fifth from the left have their right arms bent. The figure second from the left may have long hair but all others appear to be bald. The three figures descending the right side of the mountain may be gowned and face right. A figure, visible only from the neck up, stands in front of the cave in the center of the mountain, facing away. At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The topmost figure is visible as a sketchy upper body, facing forward and perhaps slightly right. The second figure from the top is visible as a sketchy head and upper body, facing forward and perhaps slightly right. The third figure from the top is visible as a sketchy head and upper body, facing forward and to the left, and perhaps bending forward slightly. The fourth figure from the top appears to be a nude male, facing forward and left and looking down. Both arms are at his side, with his left palm down and his right hand holding a walking stick. His left leg is bent and extended backward. He may have short hair. The fifth figure from the top is gowned and perhaps bald, facing forward and slightly left. Its left leg is bent and extended backward slightly. Its arms are bent to hold what appears to be an infant. The sixth figure from the top appears to be an infant, facing forward and right. It may be swaddled in cloth. The bottommost figure of this group appears to be a gowned male with a bald crown but possibly short hair below that. His arms are at his side with his right arm bent slightly and his right hand holding a walking stick; his left hand may hold an indistinguishable object, or his palm may be horizontal, facing down. His left leg is bent and extended backward slightly. His body faces left and forward, but he looks to the right, perhaps at the figures behind him. The third hill or mountaintop from the left, right of the house has a small cave in its front. Two figures are visible in front the cave from the shoulders up. Both face away and appear to be gowned and have short hair. They may be descending into the cave.

component.illusobjdesc: Most of the design shows an elaborate cave, bisected by a set of stone stairs and marked by four alcoves.

At the top of the stairs stands a winged, gowned female angel. She may personify Hope. She carries an (oil?) lamp, from which beams of light emanate. She faces forward but turns to look left. Her long hair is pulled up into a bun and her left arm is at her side, palm down. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and she holds the candle in her right hand. Both her feet are on tiptoe, and her right leg is bent and extended backward slightly as she descends the stairs.
The angel standing at the top of the central staircase holds an (oil?) lamp, from which beams of light emanate.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The topmost figure is a gowned female with long hair, facing right. Her right leg is bent and extended backward on tiptoe and she hunches slightly forward. Her arms are at her side but bent to hold a child, likely her own.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The second figure from the top is a child, perhaps an infant, that sits in its mother's arms. He(?) appears to be nude with short hair. His legs are bent and drawn up. He faces forward and up slightly.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The third figure from the top is a male dressed in a loincloth, facing forward and looking left. He has short, curly hair. His arms are at his sides but bent slightly, palms down. Both of his legs are bent, with the left leg extended backward and on tiptoe.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The fourth figure from the top is an old, gowned male with long hair and a beard. He appears to enter an alcove, which may lead farther downward into another section of the cave. He faces left and away, with his left arm at his side, palm downward. His left leg is extended backward and on tiptoe, with his left foot visible beneath the hem of his gown.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The fifth and sixth figures from the top are two gowned children. The leftmost of the pair is a boy with short, curly hair, who faces forward and left but looks up and to the right, perhaps at the child to the right. His legs are slightly bent and his right foot is visible beneath the hem of his gown. His arms are at his side but bent to hold the hand of the figure to either side.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The fifth and sixth figures from the top are two gowned children. The rightmost child of this pair is a girl with long hair. Her head is down with her left hand on her face. She may be crying. Her arms are at her side, with her left arm bent upward and her right hand holding the hand of the boy to the left. Her left leg is bent slightly and on tiptoe. She faces left and forward.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The seventh figure from the top is a gowned woman with long, curly hair. She is likely the mother of the three children who stand around her. She faces forward and left, but looks up and to the right. Her mouth may be slightly open. Her right leg is extended backward slightly and on tiptoe. Her arms are at her side and she holds the hands of the children to either side.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The eighth figure from the top is a gowned child of indeterminable gender, with long, curly hair. The child faces left and forward but looks up and to the right, probably at its mother. Its left foot is visible beneath the hem of its gown and its arms are at its side, its left hand holding that of the woman to the right.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The ninth and tenth figures from the top are a pair of gowned, old figures with long hair. The leftmost figure is a male with a long beard. He faces right and down slightly, looking at the figures to the right. His left leg is bent backward slightly on tiptoe. His right arm is at his side but bent and he holds onto a walking stick or cane with his right hand.

Ten figures descend the central stone stairs below the angel; these may be spirits of the deceased. The ninth and tenth figures from the top are a pair of gowned, old figures with long hair. The rightmost figure is a woman who faces right and hunches over slightly, looking down and to the right. Her left leg is bent and her arms are at her sides but bent upward, palms vertical, in a gesture of surprise. Her mouth may be slightly open.

In the top right alcove in the central cave, four figures are visible. Two gowned figures, which may represent dead bodies or stone tomb effigies, lie supine on a slab of stone or marble, which is marked with carvings of Gothic arches. The topmost figure faces forward slightly with its eyes closed.

In the top right alcove in the central cave, four figures are pictured. Two gowned figures, which may represent dead bodies or stone tomb effigies, lie supine on a slab of stone or marble, which is marked with carvings of Gothic arches. The bottommost figure faces up and may have long hair, its left arm at its side.
The top two figures in the top right alcove of the central cave lie on a slab of stone or marble, which is marked with carvings of Gothic arches along the side. It may be an altar or sepulchre.

In the top right alcove in the central cave, four figures are visible. To the right of the tomb are two gowned figures, possibly spirits of the dead, facing right and only visible as upper bodies. The leftmost figure of the pair is an old man with a bald crown but long hair and a beard. His arms are at his side but bent upward so that his hands are clasped, as though in prayer.

In the top right alcove in the central cave, four figures are visible. To the right of the tomb are two gowned figures, possibly spirits of the dead, facing right and only visible as upper bodies. The rightmost figure is a woman with long hair. Her mouth may be slightly open and she bends forward. Her arms are at her side but bent upward with her hands together as though praying. He mouth is partly open.

Two gowned figures lie in the bottom right alcove of the central cave on a partly rolled woven mat. They may both represent spirits. The topmost figure of the pair is a male with short, curly hair. His lower body faces up but he twists at the waist so that his upper body faces forward. He looks down and to the right at the face of the figure below him. His right arm is at his side but bent upward, palm raised. His left arm curves around the head of the woman next to him, cradling it.

Two gowned figures lie in the bottom right alcove of the central cave on a partly rolled woven mat. They may both represent spirits. The bottommost figure of the pair is a female whose long hair may be pulled back into a bun. She faces up, with her head bent back. Her mouth is open and her eyes are closed, suggesting that she may be sleeping, fainting, or dying. Her left arm is at her side and is resting on the ground, palm up.
The two gowned figures in the bottom right alcove of the central cave lie on a partly rolled woven mat.

In the bottom left alcove of the central cave are four gowned figures. Toward the back of the alcove, an old male figure with long hair and a beard lies supine, eyes closed. He faces up and right. He may be dead or sleeping.
The old male figure in the bottom left alcove of the central cave lies on a pillow cushion atop a stone slab carved with arches on the side.

In the bottom left alcove of the central cave are four gowned figures. Two gowned figures, possibly spirits of the dead, kneel or sit in front of the tomb. The leftmost figure is of indeterminable gender, with long hair covering its face. It faces left and bends forward, head down. The figure sits on a step, legs bent. Its left arm is bent upward, resting on its left leg, with its left hand on its face. It may be mourning or crying

In the bottom left alcove of the central cave are four gowned figures. Two gowned figures, possibly spirits of the dead, kneel or sit in front of the tomb. The rightmost figure of the pair is a female with long, curly hair. She faces away and to the left, bending forward slightly. She may look at the figure to the right.

In the bottom left alcove of the central cave are four gowned figures. The rightmost of the four figures is a male with short, curly hair. He faces away, with his lower body facing left and his upper body twisted to face right. He looks to the right as well. His arms are at his side but bent upward, palms up. His mouth may be open in a gesture of surprise. His left leg is bent backward and on tiptoe as he steps down from a stair into the alcove. He may be a spirit of a dead person.
The curved top of the central cave frames a scene at the top of the image, including four hills or mountaintops and a clear sky. The center two hills have caves visible in their fronts.

At the top left corner of the design stands a house with a thatched roof and the frontmost wall missing. Along the back wall stands an open, arched doorway. A woven mat lies on the floor, as does a pillow.

Two figures are visible inside the house at the top left corner of the image. The leftmost figure is a gowned male with short, curly hair, lying supine on a pillow and woven mat. His right arm is resting at his side and his eyes are closed, suggesting that he is dead or sleeping.

Two figures are visible inside the house at the top left corner of the image. The upper figure is a gowned female with long curly hair. She kneels(?), facing left and slightly forward. She bends down, looking at the figure to the left. Her arms are raised at 135 degrees, palms vertical and her mouth is open in a gesture of surprise and perhaps mourning.

To the right of the house that stands in the top left corner of the image hovers or flies a nude male figure with curly hair, seen from behind. This may represent the soul in the house to the left. His body faces right but his head turns to look left. His legs are together but bent and extended backward. His arms are raised at 45 degrees, palms down.

The hill or mountaintop second from the left has a cave visible in the front and ten figures climbing it. Two gowned figures facing right and ascending the mountain stand on the left side of the mountaintop. The leftmost of the two figures may be bald and has its right arm at its side. The rightmost of these two figures may be a male with short hair. His right leg is extended backward and his right arm is raised horizontally, holding a walking stick with his right hand.

The hill or mountaintop second from the left has a cave visible in the front and ten figures climbing it. The five(?) figures walking or standing on the top of the mountain face right; all appear to be gowned. The figures second, third, and fifth from the left have their right arms bent. The figure second from the left may have long hair but all others appear to be bald.
The hill or mountaintop second from the left has a cave visible in the front and ten figures climbing it. The three figures descending the right of the mountain may be gowned and face right.
A figure, visible only from the neck up, stands in front of the cave in the center of the mountain, facing away.
At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The topmost figure is visible as a sketchy upper body, facing forward and perhaps slightly right.
At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The second figure from the top is visible as a sketchy head and upper body, facing forward and perhaps slightly right.

At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The third figure from the top is visible as a sketchy head and upper body, facing forward and to the left, and perhaps bending forward slightly.

At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The fourth figure from the top appears to be a nude male, facing forward and left and looking down. Both arms are at his side, with his left palm down and his right hand holding a walking stick. His left leg is bent and extended backward. He may have short hair.

At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The fifth figure from the top is gowned and perhaps bald, facing forward and slightly left. Its left leg is bent and extended backward slightly. Its arms are bent to hold what appears to be an infant.
At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The sixth figure from the top appears to be an infant, facing forward and right. It may be swaddled in cloth.

At least seven figures descend the rightmost hill or mountaintop. The bottommost figure of this group appears to be a gowned male with a bald crown but possibly short hair below that. His arms are at his side with his right arm bent slightly and his right hand holding a walking stick; his left hand may hold an indistinguishable object, or his palm may be horizontal, facing down. His left leg is bent and extended backward slightly. His body faces left and forward, but he looks to the right, perhaps at the figures behind him.

The third hill or mountaintop from the left, right of the house, has a small cave in its front. Two figures are visible in front the cave from the shoulders up. Both face away and appear to be gowned and have short hair. They may be descending into the cave.
